Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Used for prophylaxis or nonspecific surface infection. Not indicated as empirical therapy for deep/stromal ulcers 
* Broad spectrum (G- & G+) but overall __poor__ penetration into the cornea 
* Dose for prophylaxis is typically BID 
* :cat: There is a [report](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21906985) of suspected anaphylaxis with use of topical antibiotics (e.g. TAB or terramycin) in cats. The chance of a reaction is likely extremely remote but no data is available as to how remote

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Similar to NeoPolyBac but is a __solution__ :sweat_drops: instead of an ointment 
* Used for prophylaxis or nonspecific surface infection. Not indicated as empirical therapy for deep/stromal ulcers 
* Broad spectrum but poor penetration 
* Dose for prophylaxis is typically BID 
* :cat: There is a [report](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21906985) of suspected anaphylaxis with use of topical antibiotics (e.g. TAB or terramycin) in cats. The chance of a reaction is likely extremely remote but no data is available as to how remote

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic and steroid combination.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Can used as a cheaper alternative to prednisolone acetate but potentially less efficacious for uveitis 
* Also appropriate for immune-mediated keratitis/conjunctivitis 
* Dose/Frequency varies depending on indication NeoPolyDex ointment 
* Ointment good for longer duration on surface 
* :horse: Used in treatment of ERU, ointment easier to apply

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Combination of oxytetracycline and polymixin B 
* Broad spectrum but bacteriostatic and resistance common 
* :dog: Reported to accelerate healing of indolent ulcers (TID dose) 
* :cat: Used for chlamydophila & mycoplasma (conjunctivitis in young cats) 
* :sparkles: Has other 'special' properties related to MMP activity, antioxidant activity, and anti-apoptotic, anti-inflammatory effects (poorly described & understood).

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Similar to Gentamicin 
* Primarily G- spectrum (i.e. Psuedomonas) but resistence noted in horses 
* Poor efficacy for G+ (e.g Strep) which actually comprise most corneal infections 
* Use with another antibiotic with G+ coverage if mixed population (rods and cocci) noted on cytology - e.g. Cephazolin, fluoroquinolone 
* Can be packaged with dexamethasone (e.g. Tobradex)

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* :cat: Efficacious against chlamydophila & mycoplasma 
* Primarily used when terramycin is unavailable...

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic. Wear gloves when handling.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* Broad-spectrum - including chlamydophila & mycoplasma, Staph, Strep (Pseudomonas however has resistance) 
* Greater penetrance with ointment formulation into cornea and anterior chamber 
* Has to be [compounded](https://vetophtho.org/clinics/compounding_pharmacies.html) usually 1% strength

Antibiotics.clientInfo: This medication is a topical antibiotic.
Antibiotics.blurb:
* 2nd generation fluoroquinolone 
* Good penetrance for stroma and anterior chamber 
* Good for Pseudomonas but also has some G+ spectrum as well (although increasing resistance noted in human literature) 
* Useful for actively infected/stromal/deep corneal ulcer

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medication is a topical steroid and is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Indicated for control of active anterior segment inflammation (i.e. uveitis) 
* Good penetration through intact epithelium (better than dexamethasone) 
* Dose depends on degree of inflammation (QID+ if severe, q24h-TID if less)

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medication contains a topical steroid and is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Is 10 times more potent than prednisolone but comes in 0.1% solution (vs 1% prednisolone) - so no significant difference in overall potency 
* Poor penetration through intact epithelium 
* :cat: Can be used in cats (e.g. with [eosinophilic keratitis](https://vetophtho.org/feline/feline.html#eosinophilic-keratitis)) who may be sensitive to triple antibiotic but usually more expensive by itself

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medication contains a topical steroid and is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Less expensive than prednisolone acetate 
* Poorer penetration through intact corneal epithelium but potentially can still be used for uveitis 
* Good for surface inflammation (e.g. pannus)

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medicaiton contains a steroid which is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Less expensive than prednisolone acetate 
* Poorer penetration through intact corneal epithelium but potentially can still be used for uveitis 
* Good for surface inflammation (e.g. pannus) 
* :horse: Used for ERU (BID-QID) due to ease of applying ointments (vs drops) to an equine eye - prolonged used can increase risk of fungal keratitis with ulceration

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medicaiton contains a steroid which is contraindicated with corneal ulcers. Stop and call if squinting is noted.
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Hydrocortisone is a weak steroid with poor penetration and should not be used for intraocular inflammation 
* Main indication is for mild surface inflammation

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medication is a topical non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID).
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Topical NSAID 
* Usually insufficient alone for treatment of uveitis 
* Concurrent use in cases of corneal ulceration is questionable out of concern for impairment of epithelial healing and reports of melting secondary to NSAID use in veterinary and people

Antiinflammatories.clientInfo: This medication is a topical non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID).
Antiinflammatories.blurb:
* Topical NSAID 
* Usually insufficient alone for treatment of uveitis 
* Concurrent use in cases of corneal ulceration is questionable out of concern for impairment of epithelial healing and reports of melting secondary to NSAID use in veterinary and people 
* :+1: Comes in a 10 mL bottle

Glaucoma.clientInfo: This medication is a topical medication for glaucoma.
Glaucoma.blurb:
* A combination of a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (Dorzoladmide) and a beta-blocker (Timolol) - more effect together than either alone 
* Useful for secondary glacuomas were extreme miosis is *not* desired (e.g. uveitis) 
* Start off at BID dosing (more has not necessarily been shown to be better but can do up to QID) 
* :exclamation: Rare incidences of sensitivity (i.e. keratitis) with prolonged use has been [reported](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26642138) for dorzolamide

Glaucoma.clientInfo: This medication is a topical medication for glaucoma.
Glaucoma.blurb:
* First line treatment for acute spikes in *primary* glaucoma 
* May be contraindicated for secondary glaucoma such as lens luxation or uveitis 
* Extreme miosis with use so not ideal for above secondary glaucomas 
* :cat: As most glaucomas in cats are secondary, limited use - if primary, [reported](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26183373) to work but not long-term

Glaucoma.clientInfo: This medication is a topical medication for glaucoma.
Glaucoma.blurb:
* A topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor 
* Can be given alone if there are concerns for Timolol 
* Literature describes TID dosing in dogs, BID in cats 
* :exclamation: Rare incidences of sensitivity (keratitis) with prolonged use has been [reported](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=26642138) for dorzolamide

Glaucoma.clientInfo: This medication is a topical medication for glaucoma.
Glaucoma.blurb:
* A generally 'weak' glaucoma medication, not terribly efficacious on its own 
* Useful as a prophylactic medication in an unaffected eye/dog with primary glaucoma (BID) 
* Potentially contraindicated in small animals (greater relative systemic absorption) with heart-failure/asthma

Glaucoma.clientInfo: This medication is a topical medication for glaucoma.
Glaucoma.blurb:
* Like latanoprost but expensive :money_with_wings: (~$50-$100 for 2.5 mL) 
* Anecdotally used as a 'rescue' treatment for when glaucoma becomes refractory to traditional latanoprost/Cosopt therapy - usually effects are short-lived

KCS.clientInfo: This medication is a topical tear stimulant. Refill when necessary to continue long-term until otherwise directed.
KCS.blurb:
* Immunomodulatory agent/lacromimetic 
* Usually indicated for KCS although can also use for immune mediated keratitis (e.g. pannus) 
* Initial dose is usually BID, can be given TID in severe cases 
* Does *not* penetrate intraocularly 
* Can be [compounded](https://vetophtho.org/clinics/compounding_pharmacies.html) into 1 and 2% suspensions if higher dose indicated (refractory or severe cases)

KCS.clientInfo: This medication is a topical tear stimulant. Refill when necessary to continue long-term until otherwise directed.
KCS.blurb:
* Immunomodulatory agent/lacromimetic 
* Usually indicated for KCS although can also use for immune mediated keratitis (e.g. pannus) 
* Initial dose is usually BID, can be given TID in severe cases 
* Does *not* penetrate intraocularly, only effective for cornea/conjunctiva 
* Has to be [compounded](https://vetophtho.org/clinics/compounding_pharmacies.html)

KCS.clientInfo: This medication is a topical tear stimulant. Refill when necessary to continue long-term until otherwise directed.
KCS.blurb:
* Similar to cyclosporine (although 10 times more potent) 
* Immunomodulatory agent/lacromimetic 
* Compared to cyclosporine for KCS, not necessarily better, but can work better in some patients 
* Usually indicated for KCS although can also use for immune mediated keratitis (e.g. pannus) 
* Initial dose is usually BID, can be given TID in severe cases 
* Does *not* penetrate intraocularly, only effective for cornea/conjunctiva 
* Has to be [compounded](https://vetophtho.org/clinics/compounding_pharmacies.html)

KCS.clientInfo: This is a topical artificial tear gel.
KCS.blurb: * Provides prolonged lubrication vs eye drops

KCS.clientInfo: This is a topical artificial tear ointment.
KCS.blurb: * Provides prolonged lubrication vs gel or drops

Misc.clientInfo: This is a component of blood that is used to slow or prevent degradation of the cornea.
Misc.blurb:
* Main indication is for melting corneal ulcers or stromal ulcers where it's obvious some stromal lysis has happened and potentially will continue 
* [Recent study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28414606) showed no improvement in healing times for indolent ulcers, neither did [platelet rich plasma](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30272521) 
* Frequency dependent on degree of melting/lysis present - actively melting: q1-2h, stablizing ulcer: q4-6h, epithelializing: q8-12h

Misc.clientInfo: This medication is to help dilate the pupil and improve comfort. Effects can last up to a couple weeks in a normal eye - please wash your hands after use. Atropine is very bitter and may induce drooling if it drains down to the nose where it can be licked.
Misc.blurb:
* Used primarily for cycloplegia to reduce ciliary body spasm (e.g. ulcerative keratitis) or to dilate the pupil (to prevent 360 degree synechiae and iris bombe) in uveitis 
* Frequent use can result in decreased tear production so care should be taken with concurrent KCS (at least add in frequent lubrication) 
* :horse: Atropine can slow GI motility which is a concern for colic - however, there is scant evidence of this and [a](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29154707) [few](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27308887) [studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22657933) suggesting there is no significant clinical effect of topical atropine (up to QID) in horses 
* :tongue::sweat_drops: Solution can drip down the nasolacrimal duct and result in significant drooling (medication is quite bitter), ointment can too - maybe less likely.

Misc.clientInfo: This medication is to help dilate the pupil.
Misc.blurb:
* Used primarily for short-acting mydriasis - quick acting (15-30 min effect) with limited duration of effect (few hours depending on species) 
* Limited cycloplegia so not as useful as atropine for ciliary body spasm

Misc.clientInfo: This medication is used to help stimulate tear production. Increase dose by 1 drop per day until soft stools are noted then back down to previously administered dose. E.g. 2 drops AM & PM x2-3d, then 2 drops AM & 3 drops PM x2-3d, then 3 drops AM & 3 drops PM x2-3d, soft stools -> return to 2 drops AM & 3 drops PM until recheck.
Misc.dose: 2 drops for every 20 lbs of weigh orally twice daily with food
Misc.blurb:
* Rarely used except for neurogenic KCS, anecdotal/questionable efficacy 
* Increase oral dose until toxicity (SLUD) noted - usually in the form of :poop: soft stools (ask owner to monitor stools)
